13075.title: evening dress
13075.description: black and white silk satin and silk crepe evening gown with belt
13075.provenance: Lorraine DeAngelis, New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York); given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (1984).

extended_text.content: Blass’s iconic aesthetic, as well as his notorious charm, helped him cultivate a loyal following of influential women who became longtime fans of his work. His clients included the first ladies Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush, as well as actress Candice Bergen and philanthropist Brooke Astor. In keeping with the opulent trends of the 1980s, Blass created ornate and lavish designs while experimenting with his treatment of fabrics. This dramatic floor-length evening gown boasts an oversized white satin collar faux tied at the center front, with long streamers extending past the knee. The waistline is marked by a black satin belt. The design of the dress, inspired by menswear, is evocative of the formality attributed to a gentleman’s tuxedo.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

13075.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

22266.title: evening ensemble
22266.description: wool and silk embroidered with glass beads, trimmed with fur
22266.provenance: Betty Furness (1916-1994), New York, New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1986.
22266.dimensions:
A) tunic: length 27-1/2 in. 
B) skirt: length 43-1/4 in.

extended_text.content:
Norell was the first American designer to have his name on a dress label. Simple, elegant and well-made clothes that would last and remain fashionable for many years became the hallmark of Norman Norell.

This elegant ensemble embodies everything that Norell was about. The lampshade-shade top, which is elegantly embroidered all over with bugle beads, is edged with mink. A simple, straight-cut long skirt completes the outfit. This silhouette was made popular around 1910 and was again introduced in the 1930s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

22266.exhibit_history:
Four Decades of Fashion: Selections from the Collection
February 7-March 28, 1987
IMA- Columbus

All That Glitters
Paul Textile Arts Gallery
October 26, 2002- May 4, 2003

32221.title: Rodeo Queen
32221.credit_line: Carl H. Lieber Memorial Fund, Miscellaneous Print Fund

extended_text.content:
Jiménez employed a muscular drawing style that translated directly into the robust and viral forms of his monumental fiberglass sculpture.

Born in the Mexican-American barrio of El Paso, Jiménez embraced the Southwest's clash of cultures in his mature work.

"For years I worked on a paper that was somewhere around 27-3/4 inches by 39-3/4 inches.  That was a size that enabled me to draw with my entire arm instead of drawing with my hand, because I draw differently with my entire arm than I do with my hand.  And I love to get into a drawing."
-Luis Jiménez, 1985
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

28004.title: Nocturne: Palaces
28004.series_title: A Set of Twenty-Six Etchings (Second Venice Set)
28004.credit_line: Mrs. Pierre F. Goodrich Endowed Art Fund, Miscellaneous Print Fund
28004.inscription: monogrammed in pencil, on tab below image, L.L.: butterfly imp.

extended_text.content:
Gazing from his studio on the banks of the Thames in 1888, J.A.M. Whistler described the descending veil of night clothing the far shore in poetry. Warehouses were transformed into palaces, and tall buildings became bell towers. For Whistler, at that moment, London became Venice. The artist had made his first and only visit to Venice in September 1879, commissioned by London's Fine Art Society to produce twelve etchings in three months. Fourteen months later, Whistler returned to London carrying fifty etched plates-including Nocturne: Palaces. The palazzi may well be those along the rio di San Severo, near Whistler's lodgings on the Venetian lagoon, but the architecture was not his principal interest. Scores of etchers since the time of Canaletto, a century before, had already admirably depicted all of Venice's Byzantine-inspired tracery. What fascinated Whistler were the shifting lights and changing moods of the city.

He evoked a warm Venetian night-a single gas lantern magically revealing phantasms of palaces, canal, bridge, and gondola-by means of a subtle application and management of ink washes on the etching plate. Whistler trusted no one but himself to ink and print his Venetian etchings, and to identify these prints as his work from beginning to end, he marked each impression with his signature butterfly, making these the first pencil-signed limited-edition prints.

I have learned to know a Venice in Venice that the others never seem to have perceived.
-J.A.M. Whistler, 1880
extended_text.content_type: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)
extended_text.title: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)

extended_text.content:
Whistler was commissioned to make etchings of Venice in September 1879. Scores of etchers had previously depicted Venice's architectural beauties, but Whistler was fascinated by the changing moods and shifting lights of the city.

Nocturnal effects were recaptured by leaving a film of ink on the etching plate, which had to be reapplied for each printing. Whistler trusted no one but himself to ink and print these moody impressions.

"I have learned to know a Venice in Venice that the others never seem to have perceived."
-J.A.M. Whistler, 1880
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

2905.title: L - SF - ES #1
2905.credit_line: Carl H. Lieber Memorial Fund, Miscellaneous Print Fund
2905.inscription: signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Tworkov/79 | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  "23/25";  L.C.:  "L - SF - ES #1"

extended_text.content:
Tworkov was one of the founders of the Abstract Expressionist movement in the 1940s, but adopted an analytic approach in the last decade of his career based on geometric grids and color progressions.

"I came to the conclusion that the subconscious was banal.  I began looking for some kind of form for constants that you could hold onto."
-Jack Tworkov, 1982
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

29039.title: Sergeant First Class I
29039.credit_line: Miscellaneous Print Fund, Herbert F. Krimendahl Memorial Fund, Jacob Metzger Memorial Fund
29039.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  "2/25";  L.C.:  "Sergeant First Class - State I" | signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Jeanette Pasin Sloan 86

extended_text.content:
In 1975, Jeanette Sloan began draping brilliant fabrics as backdrops for the staging of carefully selected polished and lustrous objects that bent, distorted and reflected their surroundings including, frequently, the artist herself.

"The objects that I used were domestic things familiar to me, and I was able to arrange them formally so that the arrangements were controlled, harmonious and ordered . . . I learned that relationships are complicated and always changing-that a life must be recomposed continuously."
-Jeanette Pasin Sloan
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

10979.title: Sergeant First Class
10979.credit_line: Miscellaneous Print Fund, Herbert F. Krimendahl Memorial Fund, Jacob Metzger Memorial Fund
10979.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  "2/25";  L.C.:  "Sergeant First Class" | signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Jeanette Pasin Sloan 86

extended_text.content:
When Sloan began her long-standing collaboration with Landfall Press in 1977, she typically supplemented the full color image with a smaller edition of the basic black and white lithograph that held the purity of the drawing.

The colors and stripes of the fabric paralleled the chevrons of a Sergeant First Class insignia.

"I like my work when the line is fine."
-Jeanette Pasin Sloan
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

22762.credit_line: Gift of Eleanore R. Carruth from the collection of the late Ruth Kresge Nugent-Head
22762.provenance: Collection of Ruth Kresge Nugent-Head; Eleanore R. Carruth, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1989.

extended_text.content:
Mainbocher was the first American designer to break into the Paris fashion world. In 1930 he opened his own shop in Paris and catered to an American upperclass clientele who lived in or traveled to Europe. One of his more famous clients was Mrs. Wallis Simpson, for whom he designed a wedding gown and trousseau when she married the former King of England in 1937.

About 1940, before the outbreak of the war, Mainbocher moved to New York, where he established his couture house and ran a successful business until his retirement in 1971. He was the most expensive American couturier, and his elegant clothes were considered classics.

Mainbocher is credited with several important innovations, among them the first strapless evening dress, which he introduced in 1934. He is also famous for elegant and simple suits, an example of which is in the exhibition. The suit features a knee-length skirt with a sculpted, double-breasted short jacket in soft, lightweight wool. The suit, with its padded shoulders and its constructed look, has the characteristic silhouette of the 1940s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

22762.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

18182.title: skirt suit with stole
18182.title_notes: A) jacket B) skirt C) stole
18182.description: two-piece skirt suit with matching mink stole
18182.credit_line: Gift of Kerry Sullivan Courtois in memory of her mother, Edna O'Donoghue Sullivan
18182.provenance: Edna O'Donoghue; Kerry Sullivan Courtois, Port Washington, New York; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1996.
18182.dimensions:
A) jacket: length 16-3/8 in.
B) skirt: length 25-1/2 in. 
C) stole: 54-7/16 x 15-1/8 in.

extended_text.content: In 1973, a gift of five dresses from the estate of Norman Norell established the Indiana fashion Design Collection. Norell, who was born in Noblesville, is considered one of the foremost American designers. This dress was made by Norman Norell for the donor’s mother, Mrs. Edna O’Donoghue Sullivan for her daughter’s wedding. Mrs. Sullivan was the directress of Norman Norell’s company for more than twenty years and was one of the fashion models for Hattie Carnegie when Norell worked for her as a designer in the 1930s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

18182.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

5310.title: tunic and trousers
5310.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Marvin W. Farber (Jane)
5310.dimensions:
A) blouse: 37 3/4 x 28 1/2 in.
B) slacks: L: 41 1/2 in.

extended_text.content:
The fabric of this tunic features abstracted Lychnis chalcedonica, commonly known as MalteseCross, roses and large leaves. The flat, stylized pattern displays the designer’s attention to scale and proportion.

During the 1970s, Mary McFadden was frequently featured in Vogue for her unique look, which was based on her love of ancient and ethnic cultures. Strong interest in her style motivated major department stores to approach her and request similar versions for sale. McFadden’s tunic ensembles were regularly worn as evening wear because she focused on comfort and combined exquisite fabrics with exotic detailing.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

5310.exhibit_history:
Fashion in Bloom
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
on view (July 7, 2009-January 2010)
*rotation*

extended_text.content:
In 1970, Halston was influenced by Issey Miyake's use of Ultrasuede in his collections. Halston started using the fabric and revolutionized the industry. Ultrasuede was practical because it was machine washable and wrinkle-resistant.

The Ultrasuede day suit was a staple in almost every woman's wardrobe.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

6614.title: evening dress
6614.description: large scale print and graphic, hand rolled hem, hand painted , straight sheath dress
6614.provenance: Mrs. Hiram McKee, Indianapolis; Indianapolis Museum of Art (October , 1975).

extended_text.content:
Hand-painted stylized hibiscus blossoms adorn the fine silk chiffon of this dress. Trigère often used bold prints to complement the structure of her clothes. In this dress, the stamen of the top left hibiscus is accentuated by the gathered fabric of the drape.

The A-line shift dress prevailed as the fashionable 1960s silhouette. This style, based on the letter A, was modified in many ways to create the desired look.

Born in France, Pauline Trigère founded the House of Trigère in New York in 1942. Her elegant and practical clothing made her popular with American women.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

6614.exhibit_history:
Fashion in Bloom
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, Indianapolis Museum of Art
April 4, 2009 to January 31, 2010

17248.title: sofa
17248.description: Sofa with serpentine crest rail continuous with arms. Crest carved as a laurel rope centering a group of flowers and a spray of foliage. Serpentine seat fail centering swagged laurel roping. Four cabriole front legs.
17248.credit_line: Gift of the Children of J.K. Lilly, Jr.
17248.provenance: J.K. Lilly, Jr. (1893-1966); Ruth Lilly (1915-) and J.K. Lilly III (1916-1995); the Art Association of Indianapolis.

11965.title: Dr. Zarkhov's Tower
11965.description: blown in seven parts of colorless glass with applied aluminum luster, glued; chromed metal base [per "Exploring Art at the IMA," IMA, 1993] ; blown glass construction with silver luster ; with polished stainless steele base [catalog form in historical file] ; colorless, blown in seven parts, applied platinum luster, chromed metal base [Journal of Glass Studies 35 (1993), copy in historical file, referring to this IMA example]. Language for medium/support used in Masters of Contemporary Glass (IMA, 1997), cat. 40: Blown glass with platinum luster, glued, and chromed metal base
11965.credit_line: Gift of Marilyn and Eugene Glick
11965.medium_support: blown in seven parts of colorless glass, applied platinum, assembled and bonded; metal base
11965.inscription: Signed and dated, side, near top edge of bottom sphere: Joel Philip Myers 1972

22753.title: projectile point
22753.creation_notes: "Earliest" date = 3000 BC because that is the earliest artifact from the Native Arts of the Americas collection known to have been made in the (now) US;"Latest" date = accession year. These fields are filled out somewhat arbitrarily for search purposes only; the Earliest/Latest dates were not provided by Mellon Curator Dr. Christian Feest and should not be used or provided outside the IMA.
